title: Courage to Act: Rescue in Denmark
subtitle: at Local Projects, for the Museum of Jewish Heritage
tagline: Exhibition for all ages on the rescue of Danish Jews during the Holocaust.
desc:
Courage to Act: Rescue in Denmark at the Museum of Jewish Heritage is an all-ages exhibition about the experience of Danish Jews during the Holocaust. The exhibition walks visitors through several stories, including the story of Gerda III, a boat used to rescue and transport approximately 300 Jews from Denmark to Sweden.

While interning in the Visual Experience Design department at Local Projects, I helped with the project’s final design phase. Working with my supervisor Olivia Crosby, I refined the exhibition’s typographic hierarchy and created dozens of final elevation schematics that were distributed to a the exhibition’s illustrator.

Documentation by Local Projects.

thumbnail.alt: Courage to Act: Rescue in Denmark

title: Scent Discovery
subtitle: at Local Projects, for the World of Coca-Cola
tagline: Sensory exhibit at the World of Coca-Cola.
desc:
The Scent Discovery exhibit at World of Coca-Cola is an immersive experience that focuses on the sense of smell. Entering the exhibit, visitors are greeted with an interactive wall containing a variety of distinct smells. This section leads to a guided game in which visitors have to guess the correct scent out of a series of options.

While interning in the Visual Experience Design department at Local Projects, I helped with the project’s concept and design development phases. Working with my supervisor Olivia Crosby, I created mockups and renderings for several design directions, participated in team and client meetings, and helped push the project toward completion. The project was completed shortly after my internship was over and features iterations of my work that were refined into final designs.

Documentation by Local Projects.

title: “Nothing matches the feeling of finding treasure”
tagline: Max/MSP/Jitter video generator trying to make WordArt cool again.
desc: During RISD’s 2022 winter session, I took Mark Cetilia’s course Of Sound and Vision in which I created several generative art programs (i.e. patches) using Max/MSP/Jitter. “Nothing matches the feeling of finding treasure” explores a lo-fi, bowling alley-inspired, WordArt-esque aesthetic that makes use of Jitter’s limited typography features to generate a video from a text document.

thumbnail.alt: “Nothing matches the feeling of finding treasure”

title: Real Human Drama
tagline: Max/MSP/Jitter performance highlighting the “uncanny valley” effect of AI-generated faces.
desc: During RISD’s 2022 winter session, I took Mark Cetilia’s course Of Sound and Vision in which I created several generative art programs (i.e. patches) using Max/MSP/Jitter. Real Human Drama explores extreme uses of contemporary AI-powered creative tools, specifically GAN-generated portraits using thispersondoesnotexist.com, neural filters for emotions using Photoshop, and music generated in the style of existing musicians using Jukebox.

title: “She broke up with me on Christmas Eve”
tagline: Max/MSP/Jitter video performance stretching, distorting, and overlapping sources together.
desc: During RISD’s 2022 winter session, I took Mark Cetilia’s course Of Sound and Vision in which I created several generative art programs (i.e. patches) using Max/MSP/Jitter. “She broke up with me on Christmas Eve” features a looped and distorted a video from Cut discussing break-ups that I selected to juxtapose conclusive stories with a never-ending context. The resulting piece plays with resolution, playback speed, and video mixing. I discovered this patch also produced interesting results when combined with a video from my earlier Discotheque 1 project.

thumbnail.alt: “She broke up with me on Christmas Eve”

title: To Home?? To Home!!
tagline: Remastered instrumentals from my first album, To Home.
desc:
I wrote my first album, To Home, in high school, and it shows. But I really enjoyed writing the album’s instrumentals, and they’re easier to listen to than my voice at times. To Home?? To Home!! features remastered versions of those piano instrumentals.

The album cover is an original acrylic painting originally designed for To Home’s CD package.

title: Invisible Cities: Aglaura
tagline: Sculptures inspired by Italo Calvino’s novel.
desc:
“Invisible Cities” was the final project for Graduate Form I, which I completed as part of RISD’s 3-year MFA in Graphic Design. Tom Wedell taught the course during the Fall 2021 semester. The project required us to create a paper sculpture inspired by an assigned passage from Italo Calvino’s Invisible Cities. Additionally, we had to model and 3D print a companion piece to our sculpture.

My passage described the fictional city of Aglaura: “So if I wished to describe Aglaura to you, sticking to what I personally saw and experienced, I should have to tell you that it is a colorless city, without character, planted there at random. But this would not be true, either: at certain hours, in certain places along the street, you see opening before you the hint of something unmistakable, rare, perhaps magnificent; you would like to say what it is, but everything previously said of Aglaura imprisons your words and obliges you to repeat rather than say.”

title: “This is not a show”
tagline: Zine about performance.
desc: The final project for Nancy Skolos’ Graduate Type Studio I at RISD was to create a zine that documented our work during the semester and connected it to a cohesive theme. For my zine, I decided to typset Ashley Lee’s article “Inside the battle to change a prestigious theater festival’s ‘broken’ culture” for the Los Angeles Times. The article discusses the challenges faced by Williamstown Theatre Festival under the leadership of former artistic director Mandy Greenfield.

thumbnail.alt: “This is not a show” (detail from page 7)

title: Graphic Collages
tagline: Vector illustrations exploring dimensionality and depth.
desc: As part of my first semester in RISD’s MFA in graphic design, I took Graduate Form I taught by Tom Wedell. During the course, I created several abstract vector illustrations that pulled forms from collaged magazines. The design objective was to create a visually complex composition with dimensionality and depth.

title: Paper Sculptures
tagline: Experiments in form and photography.
desc: As part of my first semester in RISD’s MFA in graphic design, I took Graduate Form I taught by Tom Wedell. During the course, I created several architectural forms using paper, with the objective of designing graphic compositions via photography.

title: London Underground Map
tagline: Essay and poster about the design history of the London Underground Map.
desc: As part of RISD’s MFA in Graphic Design, I took Doug Scott’s History of Graphic Design course. In this course, I was tasked with writing an essay and designing a poster that researched the history of a major piece of design history. My assigned subject was Henry (or Harry) Beck’s London Underground Map, so I created a poster that matched his original map’s visual direction.

title: Paul Schuitema and Matías Duarte
tagline: Book detailing the lives and careers of two influential designers.
desc:
“Two Designer Timeline” was the final project for History of Graphic Design, which I completed as part of RISD’s 3-year MFA in Graphic Design. Doug Scott taught the course during the Fall 2021 semester.

For the project, I was assigned the Dutch De Stijl designer Paul Schuitema. I chose Google’s Vice President of Design Matías Duarte as a contemporary designer to compare Schuitema’s work against. The finished book functions as a do-si-do accordion, consisting of 38 10"x10" pages arranged in two 19-page runs. Duarte was born the same year Schuitema passed away, so the book forms a continuous timeline.

title: “Image”
tagline: Essay and poster about the word “image.”
desc: “Image” is an original essay typeset in the form of a poster. I created the project as part of RISD’s MFA in Graphic Design during the Graduate Seminar I course taught by Anther Kiley. The poster dissects the word “image” and features several examples of the word’s multiple meanings.

title: Memory Book
subtitle: for Central Synagogue
desc: The Memory Book memorializes the congregants or family members who recently passed away.

title: 5782 Clergy Card
subtitle: for Central Synagogue
tagline: Holiday card commemorating a return to limited in-person services.
desc: As an annual tradition, Central Synagogue’s lead clergy members send all of their congregants a holiday card commemorating another year of worship. To honor their first year of returning to limited in-person services since COVID, I designed a card that highlighted Central’s connection to NYC’s unique community and culture.

title: The Neighborhood @ Central Synagogue
subtitle: for Central Synagogue
tagline: Identity and website for the synagogue’s congregant-centered worship community.
desc:
The Neighborhood is Central Synagogue’s initiative focusing on congregant-centered worship, as opposed to synagogue-centered worship. Members of The Neighborhood receive exclusive virtual benefits meant as supplements to traditional synagogue membership and attendance.

As with Sharing Our Stories before, I developed the program’s visual identity and website. In this case, we went with a playful, handdrawn aesthetic that emphasizes a more casual community built around friendliness and conversation.

title: Sharing Our Stories
subtitle: for Central Synagogue
tagline: Identity and website celebrating the synagogue’s congregation.
desc: Sharing Our Stories is Central Synagogue’s initiative highlighting congregants rather than the synagogue itself. For this project, I developed a visual identity and website that marketed workshops for congregants as well as archived the projects created in such workshops. The brand’s visual identity drew on the themes of conversation, language, and the unique and diverse personalities of Central’s congregation.

title: Acts of Loving Kindness
subtitle: for Central Synagogue
tagline: Publication recognizing the synagogue’s fundraising accomplishments.
desc: In addition to designing the identity for their virtual High Holy Days services, I began a long-term collaboration with Central Synagogue on a variety of print and digital projects. The first of these projects was “Acts of Loving Kindness,” which recognized various funds and their respective donors for the prior year.

title: 2021 Season Visual Direction
subtitle: for Williamstown Theatre Festival
tagline: Key art and identity for the festival’s return to in-person performances.
desc:
Williamstown Theatre Festival’s 2021 summer season was the company’s return to in-person theater since COVID. I was entering my third year of collaboration with the organization, and the team was looking for ways to adapt the classic show-centric key art into something more unified and flexible. We didn’t know what the summer was going to consist of, but we knew it was going to be outdoors and unlike past seasons.

My visual direction embraced two challenges necessitated by COVID safety protocols: the need to hold shows outside, and the need for more digital materials. This manifested in an overarching identity showcasing the performance locations, as well as a digital program website uniting the production credits under one umbrella.

The season’s specific programming was very much in flux when we began drafting key art and titles. To start, I explored minimalistic designs featuring a central object and distinct color for each production. At this point in the design process, the team began using a consistent naming scheme for referring to the three planned productions, with each show’s title utilizing the word “Outside” followed by the show’s performance location. As the shows gradually took shape, we ended up moving away from the object-centric design style in favor of key art that depicted the performance locations. The resulting branding was more neutral and upbeat in tone.

In 2020, Williamstown and I explored a new program concept in which I designed and developed a custom website to host show credits. I took this concept a step further in 2021, integrating the show art directly into the program.

thumbnail.alt: Williamstown Theatre Festival 2021 Season Visual Direction

title: 2021 Gala
subtitle: for Williamstown Theatre Festival
tagline: Identity and invite for the theater company’s annual fundraiser.
desc: Williamstown Theatre Festival’s 2021 gala coincided with the company’s return to live performances, which had been postponed since the start of COVID. For the gala’s identity, I settled on a spotlight motif that would foreshadow and reinforce this pivotal moment in the theater’s history.

assets.alt: Digital announcement (using the aesthetic of the previous year’s gala)

title: Bloxbiz
tagline: Motion logo for the advertising and technology startup.
desc: Bloxbiz (now Super Biz) is an innovative advertising and technology startup creating virtual billboards in the video game Roblox. I worked with the company to create an animated version of their logo, which draws inspiration from their playful typography and block-shaped icon.

title: Season on Audible Digital Program
subtitle: for Williamstown Theatre Festival
tagline: Web portal for an unconventional season of theater.
desc:
Due to COVID, Williamstown Theatre Festival was unable to mount their 2020 summer season as planned. Instead of totally abandoning the season, the company partnered with Audible to rework each show as an audio play.

To support this unconventional season, I worked with the theater company on designing and developing a series of show programs in the form of a website. The Festival’s patrons could use the website as a central hub for links to each show, as well as for finding supplementary content like cast bios and artist interviews. For the program’s homepage, I pulled in screen recordings from each production’s Zoom rehearsals.

title: Hit Play
subtitle: for New York Neo-Futurists
tagline: Logo for the unique NYC theater group’s first-ever podcast.
desc: The New York Neo-Futurists (NYNF) are known for their unique brand of spontaneous theater, including their flagship act The Infinite Wrench. In place of their live show during COVID-19, the group launched a podcast titled Hit Play. I worked with the group to design the podcast’s logo and artwork, drawing from NYNF’s signature orange and the Infinite Wrench’s hexagonal icon.

title: CleverlyCo.
tagline: Stop motion-inspired identity for the playful polymer clay jewelry brand.
desc:
CleverlyCo. is an independent jeweler making handmade earrings and necklaces. The company’s earrings are made of lightweight polymer clay and feature a retro-inspired style. I collaborated with Cleverly from the brand's inception to help shape its voice, visual identity, and overall aesthetic. We settled on an aesthetic inspired by geometric-centric art movements (like De Stijl and Art Deco), and a stop motion animation style inspired by claymation and the jewelry’s clay materiality.

After a year in business, CleverlyCo. began distributing tools to other artists. These offerings included color recipes, as well as 3D-printed clay cutters that were distributed through the spin-off business Cleverly Cutters.

title: Cleverly Cutters
subtitle: for CleverlyCo.
tagline: Branding and technology for the spin-off business supplying maker’s tools to polymer clay jewelers.
desc:
After a year in business, the independent polymer clay jewlery brand CleverlyCo. began creating products for other artists. I designed the branding and technology for the brand’s spin-off Cleverly Cutters, which sold 3D printed clay cutters that let artists create specifically-shaped earrings.

To generate the cutters, I developed an algorithm using Rhinoceros 3D and Grasshopper that would turn vector illustrations into 3D models. I then printed these models myself for distribution.

title: The 24 Hour Plays
tagline: Branding and website for the action-packed theater non-profit.
desc:
The 24 Hour Plays brings together creative communities to produce plays and musicals written, rehearsed, and performed all within the span of 24 hours. Past participants in The 24 Hour Plays include TV, film, and theater stars like Jennifer Aniston, Elijah Wood, and Daveed Diggs. I worked in-house to lead a refresh of the company’s visual identity and develop a new website that brought action-packed production photography to the forefront of the company’s marketing.

This branding project originated in 2017, when I worked under a tight timeline in anticipation of The 24 Hour Musicals: Los Angeles. In two weeks, I designed and developed a new company website, migrated the site’s backend from Drupal to Wordpress, authored and implemented new branding guidelines, and created promotional materials for the upcoming musical production. In 2020, I revisited this project to refine the identity further and incorporate motion design elements to complement the company’s urgent, energetic tone.

title: Morgan & Kemp
tagline: Motion logo for a comedy duo producing online content.
desc: Morgan & Kemp was a comedy duo consisting of Joshua Morgan and Kaitlin Kemp catering to millenial humor. They reached out to me for an animated logo that could play during their videos. This resulted in four design concepts and one refined design.

title: 5781 High Holy Days
subtitle: for Central Synagogue
tagline: Visual identity for the preeminent synagogue’s first-ever virtual services.
desc:
Central Synagogue is one of the oldest, most prominent reform synagogues in the United States and the world. Located in New York, Central builds on centuries of rich history in its diverse programming, which serves more than 2,000 families.

I began collaborating with the synagogue at the height of COVID. For the first time, Central had to cater its content to a virtual audience since an in-person congregation was unsafe. To unite these virtual offerings under one umbrella, I designed an identity that referenced the ritual arch as a symbolic metaphor for a portal into the synagogue, such that congregant’s homes could become their own sacred spaces.

title: 5782 Yom Kippur Appeal
subtitle: for Central Synagogue
tagline: Annual appeal raising a majority of the synagogue’s funding.
desc: The Yom Kippur Appeal is Central Synagogue’s largest annual appeal, raising a majority of the synagogue’s funding for the fiscal year. For the project, I maintained the visual system from my previous work on “Acts of Loving Kindness” to create a cohesive print package that would reach the mailboxes of several thousand congregants.

title: Artist’s Strategy
tagline: Branding for a creative consulting team.
desc: Creative consulting team Artist’s Strategy approached me for a complete brand overhaul. To kickoff the project, I researched competitors’ branding and found an opening for a clean-but-approachable visual identity. My concepts explored ideas of implied motion and the them of finding the path forward, conveyed using imagery of arrows and divided geometric forms. In the end, we settled on a dotted path breaking through an abstract “A” symbol.

title: Motion Experiments
tagline: Vector illustration and kinetic typography.
desc:
While isolated in my parent’s basement at the start of a global pandemic, I thought it could be fun to get better at animation. So, I worked on several short projects as exercises in motion design.

These projects span two main categories: vector illustration, which consists of abstract graphics and drawings; and, kinetic typography, which is all about type.

title: Jam-A-Palooza
tagline: Motion logo and identity for a virtual music festival supporting Wesleyan University’s FGLI fund.
desc: Jam-A-Palooza was a 2+ hour virtual music festival featuring members of the Wesleyan University music and theater communities performing original songs and covers. The event served as a fundraiser for the FGLI fund, which supports students first-generation college students from low-income families. I created the event’s marketing materials, including a playful animated logo.

title: 2020 Season Visual Direction
subtitle: for Williamstown Theatre Festival
tagline: Key art and title treatments for the influential theater company’s summer season.
desc:
Williamstown Theatre Festival is an influential regional theatre in the Berkshires that has originated numerous Broadway hits and Pulitzer winners. I first worked with Williamstown as their Lead Graphic Designer during their 2019 summer season, during which I guided the marketing team through a constant stream of projects. After the summer, the company invited me to head their 2020 season’s design development and visual direction.

I worked closely with Williamstown’s communications team to design the overall identity for the summer season and key art for seven productions. For my design direction, I viewed each show’s art as its own sort of performance separate from but related to the live performance. Once we finalized the art, I animated and sound designed a sizzle reel season overview to further promote this design direction.

We completed the season branding and art over several months and many revisions, but the Festival was unfortunately unable to proceed as planned due to the COVID-19 pandemic. Instead, the season was later adapted into the Season on Audible.
tags: branding, logo, motion, music, poster, publication, video

thumbnail.alt: Williamstown Theatre Festival 2020 Season Visual Direction

title: #KeepItInPlay
tagline: Identity for an initiative supporting performing arts during COVID.
desc: #KeepItInPlay was a campaign launched in response to cancelled theatrical performances during the start of COVID. I created the identity, motion logo, and website (no longer accessible) to promote the campaign.

title: Maddie Munchies
tagline: Identity for a vegan foodie.
desc: Maddie Munchies was an Instagram account that published vegan, health-conscious recipes. I designed a motion logo that features the icon and logotype used across their social media profiles and marketing.

title: 2020 Gala
subtitle: for Williamstown Theatre Festival
tagline: Identity and invite for the theater company’s annual fundraiser.
desc: Williamstown Theatre Festival’s annual gala precedes the summer season by several months and serves to announce the upcoming shows to donors and patrons. We had not finished developing the season’s branding in time for the event, but I wanted to make sure the gala’s branding did not interfere with each show’s eventual key art. My solution was to use the company’s core typefaces set in a stark black-and-white palette with an extra emphasis on geometry and patterns. Using this aesthetic, I designed all gala materials including invites, marketing assets, and print collateral.

title: Heartbreak County
subtitle: for Ramsay Burgess
tagline: Poster for an original musical about pain, loss, and moving on.
desc: Heartbreak County is an original musical with a book by Ramsay Burgess and music by Payton Millet. I designed the identity and poster used for the show’s first few stage readings and recordings. The poster references the musical’s setting of Modest, California, a town famous for a grand arch at its entrance.

title: 5780 High Holy Days
subtitle: for Lab/Shul
tagline: Ceremonial program for a contemporary synagogue.
desc:
Lab/Shul is a multi-hyphenate synagogue that embraces a contemporary, inclusive approach to Judaism and religion. I collaborated with the team for their 5780 High Holy Days, which focused on the theme of “awe” and sought to connect congregants with the beauty of the natural world.

For this project, Lab/Shul commissioned artist Day Schildkret to create a photographic mandala created from leaves, flowers, and other organic artifacts. As lead graphic designer, I devised a visual identity from Day’s work by rearranging its component parts and creating new compositions. I then implemented this identity into print and digital assets, including a ceremonial program used during the synagogue’s services. In addition to the original program, I created several revised concepts that took the design into a more expressive direction.

assets.alt: Inside cover from the original program
Back cover from the original program

title: Something Happens for Joe
subtitle: for Williamstown Theatre Festival
tagline: Poster for Kylie M. Brown’s production of a mind-bending play.
desc: Produced as part of Williamstown Theatre Festival’s Professional Training Program, Something Happens for Joe was a mind-bending play by Philip Dawkins involving a single neverending, looping scene. I collaborated for the second time with director Kylie M. Brown to create the play’s poster, which references the play’s setting in an airport bar, and the show’s themes of repetition and psychological breakdown.

title: Orlando
subtitle: for Williamstown Theatre Festival
tagline: Poster for Katie Lindsay’s production of a play about gender and gender performance.
desc: As Williamstown Theatre Festival’s 2019 Foeller Fellow, Katie Lindsay directed a production of the play Orlando, adapted by Sarah Ruhl from Virginia Woolf’s novel of the same name. I created the poster for the play, which features a vector illustration of the gender-fluid protagonist lounging under winding tree reminiscent of the production’s set design. I designed three versions of the poster using different colors to allude to the show’s focus on the ever-changing performance and appearance of gender.

title: Tempo
subtitle: for Williamstown Theatre Festival
tagline: Poster for Kylie M. Brown’s production of an emotional play about love and technology.
desc: Produced as part of Williamstown Theatre Festival’s Professional Training Program, Tempo was an emotional play by Harron Atkins involving a confession of love mediated by a Siri-esque AI assistant. I worked with director Kylie M. Brown to create the play’s poster, which references the play’s exploration of technology’s role in our personal and romantic relationships.

title: EVO: Eat. Swim. Evolve.
subtitle: with Tong Kong, Dylan Abramson, Vanessa Tostado, and Isabela Bucciarelli
tagline: Teaching kids about evolution with an original video game.
desc:
EVO is an educational game designed and developed to teach evolution to students at Macdonough Elementary School in Middletown, CT. The game was created as part of Christopher S. Weaver’s “Computational Media: Design and Development” course at Wesleyan University during the spring 2019 semester.

The game was produced by a team led by Tong Kong, with programmers Dylan Abramson and Vanessa Tostado, and artist Isabela Bucciarelli. I served as lead artist and level designer, taking charge of the game's visual direction, graphic assets, and marketing materials.

We developed the game using Unity and conducted several field trips to Macdonough Elementary for playtesting. In that time, we settled on a 2.5D art style that kids responded well to, and simplified the game’s design to match the comfort levels of 2nd–5th graders.

During the final showcase, we were proud to watch kids enjoy our game, and were even more thrilled to hear them explain what they learned.

title: Karaoke Superstar
subtitle: for Wilson Lai
tagline: Original score for a short film about a teenage fangirl.
desc: Karaoke Superstar, winner of Wesleyan University's Steven J. Ross Prize in 2019, was Wilson Lai’s senior thesis film about a teenage fangirl trying to meet her idol, Serena, who is an online karaoke star. Wilson asked me to create music for the film’s soundtrack, so I composed a score using the sounds of phone chimes and notifications that matched the film’s themes of social media’s ubiquitous presence in our lives. The film also features original songs by Daphne Gampel.

title: Discotheques 1+2
tagline: Pair of generative art applications developed in p5.js and Processing.
desc:
Discotheques 1+2 are two generative art applications developed in Processing and p5.js. Inspired by pointillism, I originally aimed to create an interactive toy that would let users generate compositions of complex color combinations with ease. I explored this idea first in 2D with Discotheques 1 and eventually expanded the concept to a 3D implementation with Discotheques 2.

At the core of these projects was my desire to juxtapose pointillism’s analog foundations with digital technology, specifically digital screens. I focused on the aesthetic of broken digital screens in Discotheque 1 and expanded to a looser and more abstract concept with Discotheque 2.

Discotheque 2 reflects a move to 3D as well as an increased focus on the user experience. I developed a menu that allows users to control how objects are randomly generated by setting a range of values for each parameter. Other improvements over Discotheque 1 include the ability to pause all motion, export the current composition, and change the camera’s perspective.

title: Eurydice
subtitle: for Wesleyan University Department of Theater

title: Monogram
subtitle: for Wesleyan University
tagline: Official monogram for the university selected by a community vote.
desc:
Wesleyan University, my alma mater, launched their new website during the Fall 2018 semester. This launch also featured a redesign of the school’s logo and monogram. Unfortunately, the community’s response to these changes was negative, with a particularly strong vocal pushback against the revised monogram. To address these concerns, the school retracted the monogram and opened up a design contest for yet another redesign.

I entered this contest with a monogram inspired by Wesleyan’s full logo, which features a symbol evoking the school’s shield crest. The contest’s panel of judges selected my design as one of three finalists, and after a community poll my design came out on top with over 50% of 6,200 total votes. My monogram is now the official design used by the university across all official communications and merchandise.
links: Read the official announcement on Wesleyan’s blog

title: Kerfed Wood Sculpture
tagline: Fabricated sculpture made of laser-cut plywood.
desc:
In my final year at Wesleyan University, I took a course in digital fabrication taught by Elijah Huges. In this course, I was inspired by sound design and sinusoidal forms to create a modular sculpture. By laser cutting plywood with patterns of holes (a process known as “kerf cutting”), the wood becomes much more flexible and can be molded into curved shapes. The sculpture’s individual modules retained their curvature through tension via tied strings as well as glue lamination. I then stacked together multiple modules to create larger forms.

In this project, I aimed to materialize the abstract concept of sound into a physical object that references sound design in multiple ways: through the tension in the strings, the curvature of the individual modules, and the sinusoidal shapes of the laser cuts.

title: No Replica
tagline: Thesis in theatrical sound design.
desc:
No Replica was my senior thesis at Wesleyan University, which consisted of a performance and a research paper. For the thesis’ performance component, I devised a piece that used nineteen speakers in lieu of actors to investigate the role of technology in a performance context. I dubbed this piece a “sound performance,” which materialized as an immersive experience guided by limited, ambiguous narrated instructions. A pre-recorded voice led a small audience through various activities and spaces under the false premise that the audience’s behavior affected what sounds or instructions would occur. Of the ten performances, no two were the same.

Director/Sound Designer: Gabriel Drozdov
Stage Manager: Drew Weiss
Scenic Designer: Ava Calabrese Grob
Properties Designer: Capri Gehred-O’Connell
Narrator: Maddie Ulevich
Stagehand: Nika Litt
Publicist: Ramsay Burgess
Production Manager: Rebecca Foster
Thesis Tutor: Calvin O’Malley Anderson
Technical Advisor: Tony Hernandez

Part 1: Sitting, Waiting
Each performance began with the audience entering a small area enclosed by curtains. Narrated audio from two speakers initiated the show by providing some basic, loose ground rules. The two microphones situated in the space served no purpose as their cables lay unplugged on the floor. This phase of the performance included prolonged moments of silence or repeated music meant to bore the audience and raise the awkward tension, potentially encouraging individuals to act without instruction, break the ground rules, and explore the theater beyond the curtain.

Part 2: Passing Through the Curtain
Most audiences refused to move without explicit instruction to do so. After some time, the speakers instructed everyone to pass through the curtains into the main space. This main area was composed of multiple sets littered with broken or malfunctioning technology, as well as numerous speakers scattered throughout. Much of this equipment was ostensibly plugged-in and active, but only a select nineteen speakers actually worked. I included tens of unused speakers, as well other devices such as illuminated soundboards, computer monitors, and TVs.

Part 3: Shopping for Groceries
In the larger theatrical space, the pre-recorded narrator began reading an ingredient list and encouraged the audience to interact with a grocery store-inspired set. Throughout this phase, the voice would give indications that the audience’s actions were being monitored (which wasn’t true). Some audiences laughed, some stayed silent, and some chaotically began dismantling the grocery shelves.

Part 4: Driving Home
The pre-recorded voice then encouraged the audience to mimic a driving experience as if the participants were taking their groceries home. Individuals selected their “car” and the aural atmosphere of a road immersed the theater. This soundscape frequently stopped, indicating that an individual was not performing properly and as such the performance theoretically could not continue (which wasn't true).

Part 5: Reading, Wandering
Finally, the instructions led the audience to a library-esque area, but the narration provided little direction at this point. Instead, I wanted to see how participants would interact with the space when given no additional direction. The results varied again from uneventful to chaotic—individuals sat and did nothing, talked into microphones for no one listening, or destroyed the food from the grocery store. In one performance, a group of people wrapped the grocery shelves entirely with tinfoil. In another, many people gathered on the stage, which was perhaps the only true off-limits zone (as I was sitting operating the show right behind a curtain). Finally, once someone chose to exit the theater, the performance would end. An usher would enter the space to blow an airhorn signifying to all that the show was over.
links: Read the research paper, “No Replica: Aesthetics of the Performative for Automata“

title: Four Years Later
subtitle: for Payton Millet
tagline: Poster for an original musical about a post-break-up meeting in a coffee shop.
desc:
Four Years Later was an original musical with a book written by Ian Baxley and music composed by Payton Millet. The show was produced by A Class Act, NYU during November 2018 in a production directed by Korey Caron.

For the poster, I created an abstract vector illustration that referenced the show’s setting in a coffee shop and themes of conflict after a messy break-up.

title: Rhinoceros
subtitle: for Jordan Tragash
tagline: Sound design and original compositions for Ionesco’s play, Rhinoceros.
desc:
I was the sound designer and engineer for Jordan Tragash’s production of the play Rhinoceros, written by Eugène Ionesco. The play was produced by Second Stage at Wesleyan University and mounted in the Patricelli ’92 Theater during the spring 2018 semester.

For the show’s music, I settled on a mix of genres that juxtapose classical orchestrations with electronic/pop songs to reflect the play’s themes of absurdity and confusion. The score gradually devolves into an amalgamation of rhinoceros sounds, which I produced by pitching down human grunts. For the production’s sound system, I placed subwoofers under the audience’s seating such that the aforementioned rhino sounds would vibrate the entire floor of the theater.
links: Listen to sounds and music from the production

title: (at)tend
subtitle: for Wesleyan University
tagline: Poster for Katherine Patterson’s senior thesis.
desc: (at)tend was Katherine Patterson’s senior thesis in theater and environmental studies. The thesis manifested in an experimental performance that blended local farming with avant-garde theater. For the project’s poster, I created a moody collage of textures and photographs to evoke the production’s focus on nature, community, and ritual.

title: In Sync, and Out
tagline: Max/MSP audio performance creating complicated patterns out of clashing frequencies.
desc:
During RISD’s 2022 winter session, I took Mark Cetilia’s course Of Sound and Vision in which I created several generative art programs (i.e. patches) using Max/MSP/Jitter. In Sync, and Out is an audio piece combining four sine oscillators and four band-limited noise generators in a descending four-note pattern. I mainly focused on how the sounds interacted with each other, creating beat frequencies and complicated phantom sub-rhythms.

I’ve recorded several performances of the project that you can listen to below. Each is a slightly different live-tweaking of the piece’s parameters.

title: The Pillowman
subtitle: for Wesleyan University
tagline: Poster for the production directed by Eddie Torres.
desc: The Pillowman was produced by Wesleyan University’s Theater Department and directed by Eddie Torres during the fall 2017 semester. For the show’s poster, I modified a photographic self-portrait to reflect the play’s themes of interrogation, violence, psychological manipulation.

title: Falling in Love to Voices
tagline: Lo-fi album of piano demos.
desc:
Falling in Love to Voices is an album of songs I wish I had time to finish, but at least made recordings of on my phone.

The album cover features calligraphy by Maddie Ulevich.

title: Time Passes
tagline: Remake of my first album, To Home.
desc:
Time Passes is a remake of my first album, To Home this time shorter and different. I tried to make it better, but I really mostly made it shorter and different. Ah well.

Like To Home, this album is no longer available to listen to because I wrote it in high school and would prefer not to hear myself sing. If you’d like to hear the piano instrumentals from To Home, please listen to To Home?? To Home!! instead.

The album cover is an original pencil sketch.

title: Dano
links: Download the sheet music for an early draft titled “Violer”

assets.alt: Source photo, an image of my grandfather as a young adult with his family

title: Granola
tagline: Experimental pop album by musical collaborative Lola.
desc:
Granola is an experimental pop album created NYU's Clive Davis Institute of Recorded Music during the 2014 Summer High School program. The album is credited to Lola, a group that consisted of myself, Joaquin Friedman, Pavlina Osta, and Jourdan Kelli.

I was the artistic director and primary musician on the project. Joaquin was a co-producer and co-writer, assisting in the completion of several tracks. Pavlina was our chief marketing manager. Jourdan was our photographer and social media manager.

After the album’s release, I self-produced a limited run of physical copies. For fun!

title: Something Happens
links: Download the sheet music for “Come Into The Room”

title: To Home
tagline: Concept album about a failing relationship.
desc:
To Home is concept album about a failing relationship between Mason and Erin. The story is told from Mason’s perspective and is arranged in five parts that span eighteen songs. The last four songs on the album make up an EP titled More.

The parts are as follows:
One: tracks 1-3
Two: tracks 4-6
Three: tracks 7-10
Four: tracks 11-14
Five: tracks 15-18
More: tracks 19-22

The album is no longer available to listen to because I wrote it in high school and would prefer not to hear myself sing. If you’d like to hear the piano instrumentals from To Home, please listen to To Home?? To Home!! instead.

The album cover is an original acrylic painting. While in high school, I self-produced a small run of physical copies that featured 2 CDs and additional artwork. I also created a digital lyrics booklet, which featured the (semi-)original typeface Boxfish Political. I designed this font by modifying all of the letters in another font, Adobe Arabic. I was very proud of all of this at the time.
links: Listen to the remastered instrumentals on To Home?? To Home!!
Download the lyrics font, Boxfish Political
